title: 2-Chloro-2' -deoxyadenosine (Cladribine) and its Analogues are Good Substrates and Potent Selective Inhibitors of Escherichia coli Purine-Nucleoside Phosphorylase

reference.author: Bzowska A.
reference.journal-title: Z. Naturforsch. Teil C Biochem. Biophys. Biol. Virol.

subject: Cell Biology
Biochemistry
Molecular Biology

items.abstract:
<jats:p>The phase transfer method was applied to perform the nucleophilic substitution of 2,6- dichloropurines by modified arylalkyl alcohol or phenols. Since under these conditions only the 6-halogen is exchanged, this method gives 2-chloro-6-aryloxy- and 2-chloro-6-arylalkoxypurines. 2-Chloro-6-benzylthiopurine was synthesized by alkylation of 2-chloro-6-thiopurine with benzyl bromide. The stereoisomers of 2-chloro-6-(1-phenyl-1-ethoxy)purine were obtained from R- and S-enantiomers of sec.-phenylethylalcohol and 2,6-dichloropurine. </jats:p>
				<jats:p>All derivatives were tested for inhibition with purified hexameric E. coli purine nucleoside phosphorylase (PNP). For analogues showing IC<jats:sub>50</jats:sub> < 10 μm, the type of inhibition and inhibition constants were determined. In all cases the experimental data were best described by the mixed-type inhibition model and the uncompetitive inhibition constant, K<jats:sub>iu</jats:sub>, was found to be several-fold lower than the competitive inhibition constant, K<jats:sub>ic</jats:sub>. This effect seems to be due to the 6-aryloxy- or 6-arylalkoxy substituent, because a natural PNP substrate adenine, as well as 2-chloroadenine, show mixed type inhibition with almost the same inhibition constants K<jats:sub>iu</jats:sub> and K<jats:sub>iC</jats:sub>.</jats:p>
				<jats:p>The most potent inhibition was observed for 6-benzylthio-2-chloro-, 6-benzyloxy-2-chloro-, 2-chloro-6-(2-phenyl-l-ethoxy), 2-chloro-6-(3-phenyl-l-propoxy)- and 2-chloro-6-ethoxypurines (K<jats:sub>iu</jats:sub> = 0.4, 0.6, 1.4, 1.4 and 2.2 μm, respectively). The R-stereoisomer of 2-chloro-6-(1pheny-1-ethoxy)purine has K<jats:sub>iu</jats:sub> = 2.0 μm, whereas inhibition of its S counterpart is rather weak (IC<jats:sub>50</jats:sub>> 12 μm). More rigid (e.g. phenoxy-), non-planar (cyclohexyloxy-), or more bulky (2,4,6-trimethylphenoxy-) substituents at position 6 of the purine base gave less potent inhibitors (IC<jats:sub>50</jats:sub> = 26, 56 and >100 μm, respectively). The derivatives are selective inhibitors of hexameric “high-molecular mass” PNPs because no inhibitory activity vs. trimeric Cellulomonas </jats:p>
				<jats:p>sp. PNP was detected.</jats:p>
				<jats:p>By establishing the ligand-dependent stabilization pattern of the E. coli PNP it was shown that the new derivatives, similarly as the natural purine bases, are able to form a dead-end ternary complex with the enzyme and orthophosphate. It was also shown that the derivatives are substrates in the reverse synthetic direction catalyzed by E. coli PNP</jats:p>
title: Synthesis of 6-Aryloxy- and 6-Arylalkoxy-2-chloropurines and Their Interactions with Purine Nucleoside Phosphorylase from Escherichia coli
subject: General Biochemistry, Genetics and Molecular Biology

items.abstract: <jats:p>A number of 2'-deoxyribonucleosides of halogenated pyridazine derivatives were prepared by glycosylation of their respective potassium or DBU salts in acetone. The reaction yielded predominatly β-anomers that could be purified by simple crystallization or column chromatography. Of the studied pyridazines and deoxynucleosides, only 4-bromo-6-chloropyridazin-3-one and 6-chloro-2-(2'-deoxyribofuranosyl)pyridazin-3-one showed modest inhibition of CK2 kinase. </jats:p>
title: Studies on Improved Synthesis of 2'-Deoxyribonucleosides of Pyridazine Derivatives
subject: General Chemistry

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
				<jats:p> Ultraviolet and infrared absorption spectroscopy, in aqueous and non-aqueous media, have been employed to study the tautomerism of 9-substituted isoguanines, including the nucleoside iso­ guanosine. With the aid of a series of model compounds, it was shown that 9-substituted isogua­ nines, and isoguanosine, in aqueous medium are predominantly in the form N(1)H,2-keto-6-amino.</jats:p>
				<jats:p>In dioxane solution the tautomeric equilibrium is shifted in the direction of the enol form. The shift towards this form is accentuated for those analogues in which the exocyclic amino group is methylated.</jats:p>
				<jats:p>With the aid of N<jats:sup>6</jats:sup>,N<jats:sup>6</jats:sup>,9-trimethylisoguanine, and its 9-octyl analogue, the tautomeric constant was studied as a function of concentration, temperature, and solvent polarity, and the results applied to evaluate the tautomeric equilibria of 9-methylisoguanine and isoguanosine as a function of these variables. In general the enol form is favoured by a decrease in solvent polarity, by a decrease in concentration in dioxane, or an increase in temperature in chloroform solution.</jats:p>
				<jats:p>Syntheses are described for several N<jats:sup>6</jats:sup>-amino and methylamino derivatives of 2-methoxy-9-methylpurine, and 3-methyl-5-oxo-7,8-dihydroimidazo (2,1-i) purine, which served as an analogue of the unavailable 1,9-dimethylisoguanine.</jats:p>
title: Tautomerism of Isoguanosine and Solvent-Induced Keto-Enol Equilibrium
subject: General Biochemistry, Genetics and Molecular Biology
